key_title: Key to the species of Stackhousia

source.author: Barker, W.R.
source.title: Stackhousiaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Barker, W.R. (1999). Stackhousiaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Inflorescence of solitary flowers in uppermost leaf axil; small mat-forming herb
Inflorescence elongated, spike-like, with several to many flowers
Flowers arranged singly along the rachis; bracts and bracteoles at each main node in the inflorescence 1–3 in total
Flowers in clusters of 1–6 spaced along the rachis; bracts and bracteoles at each main node in the inflorescence 3–12 or more
Leaves spathulate, rounded to obtuse at the apex; cocci prominently winged; subshrubby plant of coastal dunes
Leaves obovate to linear or lanceolate, acute; cocci sculptured but not conspicuously winged; slender plants, rarely truly coastal
Bract without a swollen or saccate base, subtending 2 conspicuous green bracteoles on either side of the base of the pedicel; flowers cream to yellow; western plants of sandy country, not rhizomatous
Bract with or without a saccate base, subtending 2 inconspicuous, hyaline, often vestigial bracteoles at the base of the pedicel; flowers white to pale cream; widespread, sometimes rhizomatous
Bract without a swollen or saccate base; leaves thin; plants not rhizomatous, often branched above ground; widespread
Bracts with a saccate, often wrinkled base; leaves thick, semi-succulent; plants producing unbranched aerial flowering stems from horizontal to ascending, underground rhizomes; mostly western
Leaves reduced to scales, up to 1.5 mm wide; inflorescence with flowers usually pointed to one side; East Gippsland swamps and swampy heaths
Leaves narrowly obovate to narrowly elliptic, the broadest 1.6–7.5 mm wide, the basal ones sometimes reduced to scales; inflorescence with flowers usually pointed in all directions
